body.head: WIBARAB Feature DB: Functional requirements and Data Specification
body.p: The purpose of this TEI customization is to formalize the data structures needed to implement the WIBARAB Feature DB application. Thus, we start with a brief introduction into the most important functionalities which the application is expected to provide in Part I, a discussion of the sources feeding the database in Part II, descriptions of the overall data model in Part III and of the organization of the working files in Part IV, and finally a presentation of the formal TEI customization in Part V.

div.head: Part I: Functional Requirements of WIBARAB Feature DB
div.p: The WIBARAB Feature DB should allow researchers to explore and compare the different realizations of lingustic features in an array of Arabic vernaculars. Since the main objective of the project is to investigate the linguistic Bedouin-Sedentary split, the WIBARAB Feature DB focuses on those Arabic varieties spoken by traditionally nomadic communities and on varieties that have been traditionally classified as "Bedouin". For comparative purposes, it also includes the better documented sedentary varieties. The database focuses on a set of linguistic features that are considered especially relevant for typological purposes, and most of which have been reported in previously published academic studies to be especially salient of the speech of Bedouin communities.

In this way, the WIBARAB Feature DB represents both a specialized archive gathering linguistic data from an array of Arabic varieties, and an analytical research tool. It should thus enable the WIBARAB team and other researchers to either confirm the existence of common linguistic trends among Bedouin communities across the Arab World, accurately identifying the common features and its respective realizations, or provide sufficient data to reject the currently prevailing Bedouin-Sedentary split hypothesis.

div.head: Part II: Sources
div.p: The data included in the WIBARAB Feature DB has been extracted from three main types of sources. First, from written academic publications, secondly, data from new fieldwork campaigns carried out by the WIBARAB team in the frame of the project, and, to a minor degree, data from personal communications with native speakers of specific varieties under study.

div.head: Part III: Data Model
div.p: The data included in the database is organized around a series of linguistic features. The criteria used for the selection of the linguistic features treated rely mainly on typological considerations and on previously reported high levels of sociolinguistic salience. Every linguistic feature has a set of feature values that indicates the different attested realizations of a specific feature in the studied varieties. The documentation of an occurrence of a specific feature value(s) in a specific location is done via Feature Value Observations. Every Feature Value Observation specifies that one feature value occurs in a specific place, by a specific speaker or group of speakers. When information about the speakers and their communities is available, the sociolinguistic profile of the speaker or the community of speakers is indicated via the Person Group element, which may specify values regarding the speakers' tribal affiliation, religious affiliation, age group, gender, and mother tongue among others. When specific remarks that are not codifiable via previously explained elements are due, they are indicated in prose within the exception notes, constraint notes or general notes.
